abstract: Oxybenzone (OBZ), an active ingredient in most sunscreens, was recently shown to be toxic to humans, corals and other animals. This study is the first to demonstrate that OBZ can significantly inhibit photosynthesis and respiration in the leaves of a higher plant, cucumber. An OBZ suspension content as low as 0.228 mg/L obviously inhibited the photosynthesis and respiration of cucumber. OBZ instantly inhibits the electron transport of chloroplasts and mitochondria in cucumber leaves. Probit analysis demonstrated that the effective content for 20% inhibition of photosynthetic electron transport was 11.7 mg/L (95% confidence level). The inhibition of photosynthesis and respiration restricts carbohydrate synthesis and ATP regeneration, respectively, limiting the energy available for metabolic processes including the synthesis of vital organic macromolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids in plant cells. The inhibition of photosynthesis also enhanced the excess excitation energy in chloroplasts, resulting in overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS), and the inhibition of respiration aggravated this process. ROS accumulation adversely affects the structure and function of proteins, DNA and membrane lipids in plant cells, interfering with normal metabolism and even leading to plant death. Therefore, reducing the use of OBZ is important for protecting global ecological security.

abstract.text: Oxybenzone (OBZ), an active ingredient in most sunscreens, was recently shown to be toxic to humans, corals and other animals. This study is the first to demonstrate that OBZ can significantly inhibit photosynthesis and respiration in the leaves of a higher plant, cucumber. An OBZ suspension content as low as 0.228 mg/L obviously inhibited the photosynthesis and respiration of cucumber. OBZ instantly inhibits the electron transport of chloroplasts and mitochondria in cucumber leaves. Probit analysis demonstrated that the effective content for 20% inhibition of photosynthetic electron transport was 11.7 mg/L (95% confidence level). The inhibition of photosynthesis and respiration restricts carbohydrate synthesis and ATP regeneration, respectively, limiting the energy available for metabolic processes including the synthesis of vital organic macromolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids in plant cells. The inhibition of photosynthesis also enhanced the excess excitation energy in chloroplasts, resulting in overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS), and the inhibition of respiration aggravated this process. ROS accumulation adversely affects the structure and function of proteins, DNA and membrane lipids in plant cells, interfering with normal metabolism and even leading to plant death. Therefore, reducing the use of OBZ is important for protecting global ecological security.

body_text.text: Oxybenzone (benzophenone-3, OBZ) is a common ultraviolet absorbent widely used in sunscreens. At present, most commercial chemical sunscreens use OBZ as the main ultraviolet absorbent (Hayden et al., 1997) . Recently, with the boom of coastal tourism, approximately 14000 ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT tons of sunscreen has entered the world's coral system each year. OBZ has been identified in many water sources and is extremely difficult to be removed using conventional techniques (Samantha et al., 2018) . Downs et al. (2015) of the Haereticus Environmental Laboratory in Virginia reported that OBZ can destroy coral DNA and lead to the death of coral symbiotic algae, causing widespread bleaching of corals and severely harming marine ecosystems (Downs et al., 2015) . As a result, Hawaii Governor David Ige signed the first bill to ban the use of sunscreens containing chemicals that are harmful to coral; "the bill, which was passed by state lawmakers in May, 2018, will go into effect on January 1, 2021" (July 3, 2018, Cable News Network). However, a large number of sunscreen manufacturers have argued that the decision lacks experimental support from third-party peers and that there are other possibilities explaining the damages to coral. In addition, the American Association for Dermatological Research reported that banning sunscreen will lead to skin cancer and melanoma. Karen Glanz of the University of Hawaii Cancer Center also claimed that environmentally friendly sunscreens cost eight times as much as regular sunscreens. Because of the difficulty in deciding whether to ban the use of OBZ in sunscreen, the Hawaiian Medical Association wants experts to further study the effects of the OBZ used in sunscreen on corals and other plants.

Most previous studies on OBZ focused on human skin and animals (Kasichayanula et al., 2007; Lenique et al., 1992; Aguirre et al., 1992; Emonet et al., 2001) . OBZ released into the environment can enter aquatic systems in a variety of ways, damaging corals, algae and even higher plants (Dinardo et al., 2017) . However, until now, studies on the effects of OBZ on higher plants have been very limited. Chen et al. (2017 Chen et al. ( , 2018 recently reported that OBZ can inhibit the normal growth of plants and enhance the stress response of the antioxidant system when it enters the plant. However, whether OBZ affects photosynthesis and respiration, the two most important pathways in plants, has not yet been
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 4 reported.

Photosynthesis is the only way to use sunlight to produce organic matter and release O 2 . The organic matter produced by photosynthesis is the ultimate source of energy for almost all organisms, and photosynthesis also plays an important role in maintaining the balance between CO 2 and O 2 in the biosphere. Respiration is the central hub of energy and substance metabolism and provides ATP and carbon skeletons for all organisms. The inhibition of either of these pathways will damage the growth and metabolism of plants and even lead to their death. In recent decades, OBZ has entered marine ecosystems and groundwater through human activities (Zwiener et al., 2007; Li et al., 2007; Balmer et al., 2005; Goksøyr et al., 2009; Sánchez et al., 2015) . Downs et al. (2015) reported that the OBZ content reached 1.395 mg/L in some waters near the Virgin Islands. If OBZ inhibits the metabolism and growth of higher plants, then it will greatly damage agricultural production, terrestrial vegetation and whole ecosystems. Therefore, it is necessary to clarify the effects of OBZ on higher plants and to explore the effective content of OBZ that inhibits plants.

To answer these questions related to understanding the significance of avoiding continuous pollution of the environment by OBZ and maintaining ecosystem security, we studied the effects of OBZ on the photosynthetic and respiratory rates in the leaves of a higher plant, namely, Cucumis sativus L. (a widely planted vegetable), and investigated the instantaneous inhibition of electron transport in the chloroplasts and mitochondria of cucumber by OBZ as well as the effective contents of it. Although the higher OBZ contents used in this study do not exist under natural conditions, the evidence provided by this study will help people realize the harmful effect of OBZ on higher plants. The results of this study provide scientific evidence that supports limiting the use of OBZ.

The popular cucumber (C sativus L.) cultivar 'Jinyou 35' was used in this study, and all experiments were performed in Tai'an, Shandong Province, China. Cucumber seedlings were cultivated in a greenhouse in pots (10 cm diameter, 15 cm height) containing seedling substrate; sufficient nutrients and water were supplied throughout the growing period. The environmental conditions in the greenhouse during the experimental period were as follows: photosynthetic photon flux density (PPFD), 0-1000 μmol/m 2 /s; relative humidity, 45-84%; and photoperiod, 15 h/9 h (light/dark) with temperature ranges of 27-35°C and 19-27°C, respectively.

OBZ was purchased from the Sigma-Aldrich Company (USA). Because OBZ is insoluble in water, all liquids containing OBZ used to treat plant materials were newly prepared suspensions. We use "mg/L" to represent the OBZ content in distilled water or reaction agent. The OBZ suspensions used for the different treatments in this experiment were 0 mg/L (control), 0.228 mg/L , 1.14 mg/L, 3.42 mg/L, 6.84 mg/L, 11.4 mg/L, 22.8 mg/L, 34.2 mg/L and 45.6 mg/L. If dissolved in alcohol, these different OBZ suspensions corresponded to 1 μM, 5 μM, 15 μM, 30 μM, 50 μM, 150 μM, 100 μM, and 200 μM solutions, respectively. The OBZ suspensions were always stirred before being used to treat the plant materials. The OBZ suspensions were kept in the dark to avoid reaction with ultraviolet radiation, and they were used within 1 h.

Leaves were cut into 0.38 cm 2 discs, the discs were infiltrated with different OBZ content suspensions (0 mg/L, 1.14 mg/L, 3.42 mg/L and 6.84 mg/L) in test tubes, and the test tubes were ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT vacuumed for min to ensure that the OBZ infiltrated the leaves. Then, the discs were taken out and floated in the different OBZ content suspensions under light (1000 PPFD) for 6 h. The timespans between treatments were varied so that we could obtain materials treated with different OBZ content suspensions for the same amount of time. After treatment, the discs were taken out to measure the photosynthetic O 2 release rate and respiratory O 2 uptake rate in each OBZ content suspension once an hour using an Oxytherm oxygen electrode system (Hansatech, King's Lynn, UK) according to González et al. (2001) . An O 2 -saturated curve was established with ambient oxygen-saturated buffer to produce a 100% O 2 curve according to the instructions for the Oxytherm oxygen electrode (Hansatech, King's Lynn, UK); Na 2 S 2 O 3 was used to deplete oxygen in the buffer to establish a zero O 2 curve. Each time a new experiment began, the Oxytherm system was reset, and the O 2 -saturated and zero O 2 curves were re-established. The reaction solution consisted of 1.8 mL deionized water and 200 μL 500 mM NaHCO 3 . Five leaf discs (5×0.38 cm ) were added to the reaction, and the respiration rate was calculated according to the downward slope of the O 2 curve measured in the dark. The photosynthetic rate was calculated according to the upward slope of the O 2 curve measured under saturated light (10000 μmol/m 2 /s) after 5-10 min of light adaptation, at which point the slope of the O 2 curve was stable.
body_text.section: Effects of different OBZ content suspensions on the photosynthetic O 2 release rate and respiratory O 2 uptake rate in cucumber leaves

body_text.text: The chlorophyll fluorescence transients (OJIP curve) were measured using a Handy PEA instrument (Hansatech, King's Lynn, UK). The measurement method followed that of Strasser et al. (2000) . The leaf discs were treated with different OBZ content suspensions (0 mg/L, 1.14 mg/L, 3.42 mg/L and 6.84 mg/L) for 1 h, taken out and dark adapted at room temperature (25°C) for 30 min. The chlorophyll a fluorescence transients were measured by exposing leaf discs to a 1 s pulse of saturating ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 7 red light (5000 μmol/m /s). The analysis of the OJIP test was performed according to Strasser et al. (2000) . The parameters derived from the OJIP curves were calculated as follows (Maxwell and Johnson, 2000) :
(1) The density of active reaction centers,
RC/CS o =(F v /F m )/(V J /M o )/(ABS/CS o ), F v

/F m is the maximum quantum yield for primary photochemistry, V J is the relative variable fluorescence intensity at the J-step, M o is the initial slope of the fluorescence transient, ABS/CS o indicates absorption flux per CS (at t=0).

(2) The efficiency with which a trapped exciton can move an electron in the electron transport chain farther than Q A -, ψ o = ET o /TR o , ET o indicates electron transport, TR o indicates trapped energy by PSII (at t=0).
(3) The quantum yield of electron transport, φ Eo = ET o /ABS, ABS indicates absorption flux of PSII (at t=0).
(4) The relative variable fluorescence at the J step,
V J =(F J -F o )/(F m -F o )
, F J indicates recorded fluorescence intensity at J step, F m indicates maximal recorded fluorescence intensity and F o indicates minimal recorded fluorescence intensity.
(5) The performance index on a cross-sectional basis (at t=0),
PI CSO =(RC/CS o )•[φ Po /(1- φ Po )]•[ψ o /(1-ψ o )], φ
Po indicates maximum quantum yield for primary photochemistry (at t=0).
(6) The maximum quantum yield for primary photochemistry,
EQUATION

eq_spans.raw_str: F v /F m = (F m -F o )/F m .

body_text.text: The electron transport flux per RC (at t=0),
ET o /RC=M o •(1/ V J )• ψ o .

Chloroplast extraction was performed according to Jin et al. (2017) and Kreslavski et al. (2017) . The leaf samples (1 g) were rapidly homogenized in 5 mL grinding buffer. The homogenate was ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 8 filtered through four layers of cold-water-soaked gauze. The suspension was centrifuged at 300 g for 3 min to remove coarse matter and then at 3000 g for 3 min at 4°C. The supernatant was carefully discarded, and the pellet was suspended in 2 mL resuspension buffer and then centrifuged at 3000 g for 3 min at 4°C. The pellet was re-suspended in 1 mL hypotonic buffer. The resuspension was adjusted to a final volume of 5 mL with hypotonic buffer and then allowed to rest for min. The thylakoid membranes were collected by centrifugation at 3000 g for 5 min at 4°C. Finally, the pellet was re-suspended in 1.0 mL resuspension buffer, and the suspension was stored on ice in the dark for later use. The thylakoid membranes were used within one hour.
body_text.section: Assay of photosynthetic electron transport activities

body_text.text: The thylakoid membrane preparations were used to assay the photosynthetic electron transport (PET) activities with an Oxytherm oxygen electrode system (Hansatech, UK). Two milliliters chloroplast reaction solution, 200 μL thylakoid membrane and 50 μL 0.1 mM methylviologen (MV) were added into the oxygen electrode reaction cup, and the whole PET chain (H 2 O→MV) was measured as O 2 uptake in the presence of 0.1 mM MV under saturated light (10000 μmol/m 2 /s) (Brandle et al., 1977) .
body_text.section: Assay of photosynthetic electron transport activities

body_text.text: The differences in O 2 uptake rates between the treatments before and after adding OBZ were recorded to reflect the degree of inhibition by OBZ. The O uptake rate of the control was measured by adding 10 μL reaction agent into the 2 mL chloroplast reaction system, while the O 2 uptake rate of each OBZ treatment was measured by adding 10 μL of the corresponding OBZ suspension prepared with the reaction agent into the 2 mL chloroplast reaction system; the final OBZ contents in the system were 0.228 mg/L, 11.4 mg/L, 22.8 mg/L, 34.2 mg/L, and 45.6 mg/L.
body_text.section: Assay of photosynthetic electron transport activities

body_text.text: Mitochondria were extracted according to Millar et al. (2001) , and samples (5 g) of leaves were ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 9 rapidly homogenized in 10 mL extraction solution. The homogenate was centrifuged at 2500 g for 10 min, the sediment was discarded, and the supernatant was centrifuged at 18000 g for 12 min. The sediment was re-suspended in the extraction solution and then centrifuged at 10000 g for 5 min; then, the new sediment was suspended in mannitol buffer. The mitochondrial extraction process was completed within 1 h, and the extracted mitochondrial crude extract was preserved with ice.
body_text.section: Assay of respiratory electron transport activities

body_text.text: The respiratory rate was measured using an Oxytherm oxygen electrode system. A total of 1.8 mL mannitol buffer solution was added into the reaction cup. The maximum respiration rate (maximum respiration capacity) with sufficient substrates was then obtained by adding 180 μL mitochondrial extract, 10 μL mM ADP and 10 μL mM NADH to the buffer solution in the dark (Chance et al., 1956 ). The differences in O uptake rates between the treatments before and after adding OBZ were recorded to reflect the degree of inhibition by OBZ. The O 2 uptake rate of the control was measured by adding 10 μL reaction agent into the 2 mL mitochondrial reaction system, while the O 2 uptake rate of each OBZ treatment was measured by adding 10 μL of the corresponding OBZ suspension prepared with the reaction agent into the 2 mL mitochondrial reaction system; the final OBZ contents in the system were 0.228 mg/L, 11.4 mg/L, 22.8 mg/L, 34.2 mg/L, and 45.6 mg/L.
body_text.section: Assay of respiratory electron transport activities

body_text.text: The O 2content was detected in situ in leaf discs (0.79 cm 2 ) after treatment with different OBZ content suspensions (0 mg/L, 1.14 mg/L, 3.42 mg/L and 6.84 mg/L) under light for 6 h, using the nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) staining method according to Kawai-Yamada et al. (2004) .

After washing with the destainer (Kawai-Yamada et al. 2004) , the color densities (gray densities) of the whole discs (0.79 cm ) were analyzed using ImageJ software (National Institutes of Health, NIH, US), and the relative optical density (OD) was calculated according to the gray density. The OD ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 10 value of leaves treated with the 6.84 mg/L OBZ suspension was taken as 100%, while that of leaves treated with the other OBZ suspensions was expressed as a percentage of that in the 6.84 mg/L OBZ treatment.

At least 3 independent replicates were used in all experiments. Representative curves are presented in this article. Least significant differences were calculated using SPSS 11 software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). Standard errors were calculated using Excel software (Microsoft, Redmond WA, USA). Probits were analyzed using SPSS to estimate the effective content, taking the OBZ content as the abscissa and the probability unit of the inhibition degree as the ordinate. The effective OBZ content leading to a 20% reduction (EC 20 ) in PET was calculated with the probit-transformed responses. Fig.1 Compared to the control, photosynthesis and respiration in the leaves treated with OBZ significantly decreased with increasing OBZ contents and treatment time under strong light (1000 μmol/m 2 /s). After treatment with OBZ, the extent of decreases in photosynthetic rates was greater than that in respiratory rates. Fig.2 The chlorophyll fluorescence curves (OJIP curves) and parameters derived from these curves of leaves treated with different OBZ contents for 1 h changed remarkably, indicating that the structure

11 and function of the photosynthetic apparatus were severely damaged by OBZ (Strasser et al. 2000) . The large increase in the J step in the ΔVt curve (Fig. 2) indicated that the PET from Q Ato downstream in the electron transport chain was remarkably inhibited. The decreases in RC/CS o , ψ o , φ Eo , PI CSO , F v /F m and ET o /RC indicated that the active photosystem II (PSII) reaction centers, the electron transport beyond Q A -, the quantum yield of electron transport, the performance of PSII function and the maximum photochemistry efficiency were all adversely affected by the OBZ, and the harmful effect increased with an increase in OBZ content. Fig.3 When different OBZ contents were added to chloroplast or mitochondrial suspensions, the PET in chloroplasts and the respiratory electron transport in mitochondria were inhibited instantly. In this study, a 0.228 mg/L OBZ suspension effectively inhibited electron transport in photosynthesis (15.8%) and respiration (14.9%) instantly. The probit analysis demonstrated that the PET EC was 11.7 mg/L (95% confidence level (CL)). The inhibitory effect of OBZ on the PET in chloroplasts increased significantly with increasing OBZ content, and the PET rate was inhibited by approximately 88.5% under the high OBZ content (45.6 mg/L) treatment, which was approximately 5.6 times the inhibition observed under the 0.228 mg/L OBZ treatment. However, there were no significant differences in the degree of OBZ inhibition of respiratory electron transport among the different OBZ content treatments. OBZ was more harmful to PET than to respiratory electron transport. The mechanism of OBZ injury clearly differed between the two types of transport.
12 Fig.4 The results showed that the O 2content of leaves increased with an increase in the OBZ content.

Our study first demonstrated that OBZ has harmful effects on higher plants. Specifically, an OBZ content as low as 0.228 mg/L effectively inhibited the electron transport in photosynthesis and respiration; this content was only approximately 16.3% of a content found in the Virgin Islands (Downs et al. 2015) . By inhibiting the electron transport in photosynthesis and respiration, OBZ not only restricts the metabolism and growth of cucumber but also enhances the overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which inevitably damage the photosynthetic apparatus, cell membranes, proteins, nucleic acids, etc.

Although OBZ is insoluble in water, suspended particles of OBZ could enter plant cells through leaf margin infiltration and leaf active absorption to inhibit normal metabolism. Photosynthesis and respiration are both driven by electron transport. The inhibition of the electron transport in photosynthesis and respiration was instant. The inhibition of PET will result in the closure of PSII reaction centers (Maxwell and Johnson, 2000) ; the considerable decrease in RC/CS o in leaves treated with OBZ supported this conjecture. The substantial increase in the J point ( Fig. 2B ) and the decrease in ψ o indicated that the electron transport to Q B downstream was greatly inhibited by OBZ. Combining the effect of OBZ on PET, the OJIP curve, and the parameters derived from the OJIP test, it is reasonable to speculate that damaging the photosynthetic apparatus and inhibiting its function are two of the most harmful effects of OBZ on higher plants. Chen et al (2018) reported that OBZ treatment significantly increased the ROS in plants, and in this study, we demonstrated that with an increase in OBZ content, the ROS content increased ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 13 dramatically. Photosynthesis and respiration are the most important sources of ROS production (Miller et al., 2010) . The considerable inhibition of PET will lead to more excess excitation energy, and if this excess excitation energy cannot be safely dissipated by energy dissipation mechanisms, then ROS will be produced (Zhang et al., 2014) . The inhibition of respiratory electron transport will also inhibit the use of high energy, which will in turn enhance the production of ROS. In addition to damaging cell membranes, proteins and nucleic acids, accumulated ROS can directly damage vital macromolecules in the cell and affect other metabolic processes through signal transduction (Apel and Hirt., 2014) . The over accumulation of ROS is an important source of photosynthetic pigment damage, and if the damage becomes severe, then light bleaching of the plant will occur (Miller et al., 2010) . The bleaching of plants normally occurs under strong light, and any inhibition of the light reaction or dark reaction of photosynthesis by stress factors will enhance the bleaching. Because coral symbiotic algae also undergo photosynthesis and respiration, it is reasonable to assume that the inhibition of photosynthesis and respiration by OBZ will facilitate photobleaching of coral symbiotic algae. Therefore, we suggest that the harmful effect of OBZ on photosynthesis and respiration is one of the most important drivers of coral bleaching. The effective OBZ content causing the bleaching of coral should be clarified through additional studies.

When PET is inhibited, the light energy captured by chloroplasts cannot be converted into chemical energy to provide assimilatory power for CO fixation and reduction in the Calvin cycle, which further inhibits the whole photosynthetic process and restricts sugar synthesis and transport, ultimately inhibiting the development and establishment of new organs and decreasing the substrate for respiratory metabolism. The decrease in the respiratory substrate further restricts respiration. Because of the decrease in respiratory substrates and the inhibition of respiratory electron transport by ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 14 OBZ, the production of ATP is inhibited, limiting the energy supply for various cellular metabolisms. This limitation of energy supply is one of the reasons that OBZ inhibits plant growth and ultimately leads to plant death.

In conclusion, OBZ treatment not only directly inhibited photosynthesis and respiration but also damaged plants by increasing the ROS content in their cells. Therefore, we speculate that all organisms that undergo respiration and/or photosynthesis, including coral symbiotic algae, will be inhibited by OBZ. Consequently, reducing the use of OBZ is an important way to protect the earth's ecological security. However, the mechanism by which OBZ inhibits photosynthetic and respiratory electron transport and the sites of inhibition need to be clarified through further researches. Plant. Biol. 2004 Biol. , 55, 373-399, https://doi.org/10.1146 .

OBZ can enter cells to significantly inhibit photosynthesis and respiration in the leaves of a higher plant, cucumber. OBZ can instantly inhibit the electron transports of chloroplasts and mitochondria. The inhibition of photosynthesis and respiration would restrict the synthesis of carbohydrates and the regeneration of ATP, limiting the energy available for metabolic processes. The inhibition of photosynthesis increased the excess excitation energy in the plant cells, resulting in over-production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the inhibition of respiration aggravated this process. The overaccumulation of ROS adversely affects the structure and function of proteins, DNA and membrane lipids in plant cells, interfering with normal metabolism and even leading to the death of plant.

18 Fig. 1 : The inhibitory effect of OBZ on the photosynthetic rate and respiratory rate of cucumber leaves treated with different OBZ contents for different amounts of time; the control included leaf discs treated with water. The PPFD used to measure photosynthesis was 1000 μmol/m 2 /s, and the temperature was kept at 25°C by the Oxytherm system. Different letters at each time point represent significant differences in photosynthesis or respiration between OBZ treatments (p<0.01). Values are the means ± SEs (n=3).

19 Fig. 2 : Effects of different OBZ content suspensions on the V t curve (A) and the relative variable fluorescence kinetics ΔV t (B) in cucumber leaves after treatment with OBZ suspensions for 1 h. The ΔV t was obtained by subtracting the kinetics of the control (0 mg/L OBZ) from those of leaves treated with the other OBZ content suspensions. The fluorescence parameters RC/CS o , ψ o , φ Eo , PI CSO , F v /F m , and ET o /RC derived from the OJIP-test analysis of chlorophyll a fluorescence transients are depicted in Fig. 2 (C) . Each point represents the average of 5 samples. All parameters for the leaves of the control were taken as 1, whereas those in the leaves treated with the other OBZ content suspensions are expressed as a percentage of those in the control.The different letters beside each parameter represent significant differences between different OBZ treatments (P＜0.01). Leaf discs were infiltrated with different OBZ content suspensions (0 mg/L, 1.14 mg/L, 3.42 mg/L and 6.84 mg/L);
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 20 428

then, the leaf discs were taken out and floated in different OBZ suspensions under light (1000 PPFD) 429 for 6 h. Finally, the leaf discs were dark adapted with leaf clips for half an hour before the 430 measurement of fluorescence. respiration between the control and OBZ treatment (p<0.01). Values are the means ± SEs (n=3). Fig. 4 Effects of different OBZ content suspensions on the Ocontent in cucumber leaves. The OD value of leaf discs treated with the 6.84 mg/L OBZ suspension was taken as 100%, while that of leaf discs treated with the other OBZ contents were taken as a percentage of that in the 6.84 mg/L OBZ treatment. Different letters over columns represent significant differences between treatments (p<0.01). Values are means ± SEs (n=3).
The OBZ suspension can instantly inhibit the electron transports of chloroplasts and mitochondria of a higher plant (cucumber).
An OBZ suspension content as low as 0.228 mg/L obviously inhibited the photosynthesis and respiration of cucumber.

The inhibition of photosynthesis increased the excess excitation energy in the plant cells, resulting in overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS), the inhibition of respiration aggravated this process. The over accumulation of ROS is one of the reasons to damage plant.

BIBREF26.title: Reactive oxygen species: metabolism, oxidative stress, and signal transduction
BIBREF26.raw_text: Apel, K.; Hirt, H., Reactive oxygen species: metabolism, oxidative stress, and signal transduction. Annu. Rev.

FIGREF0.text: OBZ can enter cells in various ways to significantly inhibit photosynthesis and respiration in the leaves of a higher plant, namely, cucumber. An OBZ content as low as 0.228 mg/L had an obvious harmful effect, and the PET EC 20 was 11.7 mg/L. OBZ can instantly inhibit the electron transport of chloroplasts and mitochondria. The inhibition of photosynthesis and respiration restricts important processes such as the synthesis of carbohydrates and the regeneration of ATP, limiting the energy available for metabolic processes. The inhibition of photosynthesis and respiration also results in the overproduction of ROS. The accumulation of ROS adversely affects the structure and function of proteins, DNA and membrane lipids as well as leads to photobleaching in plant cells, interfering with normal metabolism and even leading to plant death. Authors' contributions Qingming Li, Huiyuan Gao and Xin Zhong designed the research; Yuting Li and Xin Zhong performed all of the research and wrote the article; and Xingkai Che, Zishan Zhang, Binbin Liu and Yiman Li analyzed the data. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

FIGREF2.text: The instantaneous inhibition of chloroplast PET (from water to MV) (A) and mitochondrial 434 respiratory electron transport (B) by OBZ. The final O uptake rates were calculated using the final 435 reaction agent volumes. The control (0 mg/L) consisted of placing 10 μL reaction agent into the 436 reaction cup. Different letters on columns represent significant differences in photosynthesis or437
